Description: Lower body sherd with turn to stemmed foot of South Ionian pottery little-master cup with everted rim; interior: probably disc at centre surrounded by dilute lines and two dilute bands (one at break); exterior: glazed streaky black (fired reddish in places) save for reserved band; reserved at top of underside of foot.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B3 (possibly)
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer identifies the sherd as belonging to a Type 9 South Ionian cup with everted rim. The dilute concentric lines on the interior surface suggest the sherd cannot be of his Type 9A. The concentric circles on the interior surface of the sherd find parallels with British Museum 1924,1201.1297 and 1965,0930.871. The sherd may belong to Schlotzhauer's Ionian Cup Type 9.C. This type (without the myrtle leaf pattern around the rim, which is missing in this instance) corresponds with Hayes' Ionian Cup Type X (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B3 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers at in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape.
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 49, no. 35)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.704) (Phase 3)
